thread.title: Soft Brexit, Hard Brexit, No Deal: A short summary of EU exit terms in 263 words

author: Dan Martin
title: Soft Brexit, Hard Brexit, No Deal: A short summary of EU exit terms in 263 words
text:
The UK is negotiating Brexit terms with the European Union (Image: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) Share Get Daily Thank you for subscribing!
The UK is set to quit the European Union on March 29, 2019 - the process called Brexit.
It is currently unclear exactly what Britain’s relationship with the EU after that date.
The Government and the EU are still trying to agree mutually acceptable terms.
Prime Minister Theresa May’s Chequers Proposal is widely considered to be a vision for a so-called Soft Brexit .
This would mean a continued close relationship with 27 EU member states.
It would see the UK: keeping some kind of free trade arrangement with the EU; remaining in a customs union (a group of states that have agreed to charge the same import duties as each other, usually to allow free trade between themselves); allowing EU citizens to live and work in the UK.
However, some ardent Brexiteers say such a deal would in fact not be a Brexit.
They are pushing for a Hard Brexit , which is generally taken to mean a significant change from the status quo.
This would mean the UK: leaving the EU single market and customs union; no longer implementing EU freedom of movement rules.
If the UK and the EU cannot reach an agreement a No Deal will occur when the two-year period after the triggering of Article 50 ends.
That would mean the UK’s sudden split from the EU without a transition period.
That in turn means the relationship would be governed by basic rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
And it would likely result in a big jolt to the UK economy with the loss of jobs and falling GDP. Read More
